nodes.body:
Based on contemporary experience in Repkong (reb kong) in the Amdo cultural region, in agricultural (rong) contexts, dewa (sde ba) is used with much the same meaning as the English “village.”

Sources:

Samten G. Karmay, “A Comparative Study of the yul lha Cult in Two Areas and Its Cosmological Aspects,” in New Horizons in Bon Studies, ed. Samten G. Karmay and Yasuhiko Nagano (Delhi: Saujanya Publications, 2004), 383-415 [THL ID 67344]

Charlene Makley, The Violence of Liberation: Gender and Tibetan Buddhist Revival in Post-Mao China (Berkeley: University of California Press, 2007), 67.

In pastoral (’brog) contexts, dewa is possibly used in more diverse ways. Charlene Makley, in the context of the Labrang cultural region in Gansu Province, suggests a rough equivalence with “nomad encampment.” However, Fernanda Pirie, who has worked in the Golok cultural region in Sichuan Province, reports that “nomad encampments,” as smaller residential groupings, are known there as repkor/rukor (ru skor); the term dewa is used for larger groups, which are “united on the basis of territory, rather than according to a descent ideology” (larger groups that according to other authors such as Ekvall or Gelek are also called for instance tsowa or shokwa). Pirie translates dewa as “tribal group” or “tribe”; the term dewa is also used to refer to more recently established pastoral townships (Chi. xiang).

 

Sources:

Fernanda Pirie, “Violence and Opposition among the Nomads of Amdo: Expectations of Leadership and Religious Authority,” in Conflict and Social Order in Tibet and Inner Asia, ed. Toni Huber and Fernanda Pirie  (Leiden: Brill, 2008), 217-40 (p. 221).

Charlene Makley, The Violence of Liberation: Gender and Tibetan Buddhist Revival in Post-Mao China (Berkeley: University of California Press, 2007), 67.
